title: Overall
stimulusHtml:
This question requires students to work with historical documents, describing their contents in an analytical framework. A prime focus of analysis stipulated by the directions is for students to “take into account both the sources and the authors’ points of view.” Because this was such a clearly stipulated area of analysis, some specific attention to it had to appear for a student to achieve a score in the 7-9 range, although this attention could be as minimal as citing the provenance of a document. For an essay to receive a score in the 10-12 range, the student had to make some mention of the significance of source/point of view, and for a paper to be elevated to the 13-15 category, this kind of analysis must have appeared frequently throughout the essay.

In addition, a central analytical approach was to group documents into areas of controversy. These areas involved such topics as religion, politics, cul- ture, ethnicity, economics, and nationalism. Students often simply categorized the controversy as pro- and anti-English union and incorporated the other issues into these two divisions.

Other indicators of analysis, as with all DBQs, include frequent reference to the terms of the question; juxtaposition of documents; recognition of complexities and contradictions in the documents; and the possible use of outside information to illuminate the documents. However, any outside information (more often used in these essays than in most years, as the question’s general topic is familiar to many students) must be used to enhance, not replace, analysis of the documents.

13-15 points:

Develops several controversies with sophistication, insight, and clear delineation; addresses source/author points of view evenly; uses most documents, correctly, with very minor errors;makes only very minor errors in any external background.

10-12 points:

Addresses several controversies, developing some, but perhaps treating them unevenly; alludes to the significance of source/author points of view with accuracy; uses many documents, though some perhaps implicitly; uses documents correctly (although one error in interpretation is allowable if the overall argument is sound); may offer historical background, perhaps inaccurately.
7-9 points:
Discusses one or two controversies in general terms, perhaps with a nod toward others; may group issues into simple pro- and anti-Unionist positions; uses some analysis indicators, but with minimal acknowledgement of their source or the point of view of authors (e.g.,cites the provenance of documents); uses documents generally correctly (although a few errors in interpretation are allowable); uses a substantial number of documents.
4-6 points:

Makes little or no attempt to identify controversies; offers mere description of documents, wholly uncritically, with little or no analysis; perhaps only a laundry list; uses few documents, with significant and chronic errors in interpretation.

0-3 points:

Does not meet the criteria for earning 4 points or more.
